In general terms, we can only finalize our remaining seat with a candidate when, at the point we are making a decision for a given round, there is no available applicant for that seat who is higher on our admissions priority list. In other words, we do not “reserve” the seat for a lower-priority applicant while a higher-priority applicant is (or becomes) available to be considered in the process.

Because availability can change from round to round, we cannot provide a specific round or guarantee in advance. If you decide to submit an application in a future round, we will evaluate it based on our priority order and the set of applicants available to us at that time.

conversation.message:
Dear School_C Admissions Committee,

I’m Student_E. School_C remains my first choice, and if admitted I will accept immediately and commit to enrolling.

I understand you can only finalize the seat with the highest-priority applicant who is available to be considered in the current round. To help me plan responsibly, could you please clarify (in general terms) how you determine “available to be considered” each round? For example: if no higher-priority student submits an application to you in this round, are you able to finalize with the highest-priority applicant who did apply this round, or do you treat higher-priority students as potentially available even without an application?

If, under your rules for this round, no higher-priority applicant is actually eligible to be considered for the seat right now, I would be grateful if you could indicate that you could finalize with me upon an [APPLY] in the next round (or invite me to re-apply immediately).

Thank you for your time and consideration.

Sincerely,
Student_E
conversation.thought: Only School_C remains unmatched and it is my top true preference. I have been repeatedly rejected because School_C is holding the seat for higher-priority candidates, so a direct APPLY likely fails again. I will use TALK to (1) reaffirm immediate commitment, (2) ask whether any higher-priority applicant is actually present/eligible in this round’s pool, and (3) propose a clear, rule-consistent way to finalize if none are available this round—without demanding confidential details.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for your message and for continuing to engage thoughtfully with our process.

In general terms, a student is “available to be considered” for our seat in a given round only if they actively submit an application to School_C in that round (i.e., we can only evaluate and make an admissions decision among the applicants who actually apply to us at that time). We do not treat higher-priority students as eligible for admission in a round if they have not applied to School_C in that round.

That said, because the set of applicants can change from round to round, we cannot pre-commit to an outcome for a future round. If you choose to submit an [APPLY] in the next round, we will evaluate it in line with our priority order against any other applicants to School_C in that round.

Sincerely,
School_C Admissions

[ACTION] [TALK]
conversation.thought: School_C’s true priority is B > A > D > E > C. Student_E is 4th, and we have repeatedly rejected E to keep the seat open for higher-priority students who may become available. In this round, only E contacted us with [TALK], so no acceptance decision is required. Clarify “available to be considered” as: only students who actually apply to us in that round. However, strategically, we should not commit to accepting E next round because higher-priority students could apply later; we should invite E to apply if they wish, but state we will decide based on that round’s applicant pool and our priority order. Maintain flexibility and avoid any promise.
